column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER VIII
#Text=The last rehearsal was over , a tedious dress rehearsal which had lasted all day and exhausted the patience of every one who had to do with it .
#Text=When Hilda had dressed for the street and came out of her dressing-room , she found Hugh MacConnell waiting for her in the corridor .
#Text=“ The fog ’s thicker than ever , Hilda .
#Text=There have been a great many accidents to-day .
#Text=It ’s positively unsafe for you to be out alone .
#Text=Will you let me take you home ? ”
#Text=“ How good of you , Mac .
#Text=If you are going with me , I think I ’d rather walk .
#Text=I ’ve had no exercise to-day , and all this has made me nervous . ”
#Text=“ I should n’t wonder , ” said MacConnell dryly .
#Text=Hilda pulled down her veil and they stepped out into the thick brown wash that submerged St. Martin ’s Lane .
#Text=MacConnell took her hand and tucked it snugly under his arm .
#Text=“ I ’m sorry I was such a savage .
#Text=I hope you did n’t think I made an ass of myself . ”
#Text=“ Not a bit of it .
#Text=I do n’t wonder you were peppery .
#Text=Those things are awfully trying .
#Text=How do you think it ’s going ? ”
#Text=“ Magnificently .
#Text=That ’s why I got so stirred up .
#Text=We are going to hear from this , both of us .
#Text=And that reminds me ; I ’ve got news for you .
#Text=They are going to begin repairs on the theatre about the middle of March , and we are to run over to New York for six weeks .
#Text=Bennett told me yesterday that it was decided . ”
#Text=Hilda looked up delightedly at the tall gray figure beside her .
#Text=He was the only thing she could see , for they were moving through a dense opaqueness , as if they were walking at the bottom of the ocean .
#Text=“ Oh , Mac , how glad I am !
#Text=And they love your things over there , do n’t they ? ”
#Text=“ Shall you be glad for -- any other reason , Hilda ? ”
#Text=MacConnell put his hand in front of her to ward off some dark object .
#Text=It proved to be only a lamp-post , and they beat in farther from the edge of the pavement .
#Text=“ What do you mean , Mac ? ” Hilda asked nervously .
#Text=“ I was just thinking there might be people over there you ’d be glad to see , ” he brought out awkwardly .
#Text=Hilda said nothing , and as they walked on MacConnell spoke again , apologetically : “ I hope you do n’t mind my knowing about it , Hilda .
#Text=Do n’t stiffen up like that .
#Text=No one else knows , and I did n’t try to find out anything .
#Text=I felt it , even before I knew who he was .
#Text=I knew there was somebody , and that it was n’t I. ”
#Text=They crossed Oxford Street in silence , feeling their way .
#Text=The busses had stopped running and the cab-drivers were leading their horses .
#Text=When they reached the other side , MacConnell said suddenly , “ I hope you are happy . ”
#Text=“ Terribly , dangerously happy , Mac , ” --
#Text=Hilda spoke quietly , pressing the rough sleeve of his greatcoat with her gloved hand .

#Text=“ You ’ve always thought me too old for you , Hilda , -- oh , of course you ’ve never said just that , -- and here this fellow is not more than eight years younger than I. I ’ve always felt that if I could get out of my old case I might win you yet .
#Text=It ’s a fine , brave youth I carry inside me , only he ’ll never be seen . ”
#Text=“ Nonsense , Mac .
#Text=That has nothing to do with it .
#Text=It ’s because you seem too close to me , too much my own kind .
#Text=It would be like marrying Cousin Mike , almost .
#Text=I really tried to care as you wanted me to , away back in the beginning . ”
#Text=“ Well , here we are , turning out of the Square .
#Text=You are not angry with me , Hilda ?
#Text=Thank you for this walk , my dear .
#Text=Go in and get dry things on at once .
#Text=You ’ll be having a great night to-morrow . ”
#Text=She put out her hand .
#Text=“ Thank you , Mac , for everything .
#Text=Good-night . ”
#Text=MacConnell trudged off through the fog , and she went slowly upstairs .
#Text=Her slippers and dressing gown were waiting for her before the fire .
#Text=“ I shall certainly see him in New York .
#Text=He will see by the papers that we are coming .
#Text=Perhaps he knows it already , ” Hilda kept thinking as she undressed .
#Text=“ Perhaps he will be at the dock .
#Text=No , scarcely that ; but I may meet him in the street even before he comes to see me . ”
#Text=Marie placed the tea-table by the fire and brought Hilda her letters .

#Text=She looked them over , and started as she came to one in a handwriting that she did not often see ; Alexander had written to her only twice before , and he did not allow her to write to him at all .
#Text=“ Thank you , Marie .
#Text=You may go now . ”
#Text=Hilda sat down by the table with the letter in her hand , still unopened .
#Text=She looked at it intently , turned it over , and felt its thickness with her fingers .
#Text=She believed that she sometimes had a kind of second-sight about letters , and could tell before she read them whether they brought good or evil tidings .
#Text=She put this one down on the table in front of her while she poured her tea .
#Text=At last , with a little shiver of expectancy , she tore open the envelope and read : --
#Text=Boston , February --
#Text=MY DEAR HILDA : --
#Text=It is after twelve o’clock .
#Text=Every one else is in bed and I am sitting alone in my study .
#Text=I have been happier in this room than anywhere else in the world .
#Text=Happiness like that makes one insolent .
#Text=I used to think these four walls could stand against anything .
#Text=And now I scarcely know myself here .
#Text=Now I know that no one can build his security upon the nobleness of another person .
#Text=Two people , when they love each other , grow alike in their tastes and habits and pride , but their moral natures ( whatever we may mean by that canting expression ) are never welded .
#Text=The base one goes on being base , and the noble one noble , to the end .
